title: Are Catholic Albanians the original Albanians? My Albanians friend say that the Catholics in Albania are the true Albanians. - Quora

response.answer_text: I am going to pretend you didn’t use the phrase ‘true Albanians’, because confession doesn’t determine what a ‘true’ Albanian is. All Albanians, whatever they may believe in, are ‘true’ Albanians. Concerning the first part of your question, wether catholicism is the ‘original’ as in ‘first’ christian confession of Albanians: In theory, yes. But it’s more complicated than just saying ‘yes’ here: Catholicism and Orthodoxy split into two separate confessions only with the Great Schism in 1054, in which the Byzantine Eastern Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Church split from each other. During the Great Schism, practically all Albanians were orthodox, due to centuries of Byzantine rule. Albanians were already christianized way before that though - under Roman rule before the 5. Century. So the first Albanian non-pagan religion was neither Catholic nor Orthodox, as neither existed back then. It was simply Christianity. And at the point of Catholicism and Orthodoxy spliting into separate confessions, Albanians were following the Byzantine rite of Orthodoxy.There is a catch though: in antiquity, during the Roman rule in the Balkans (roughly 150BC-450AD), the Balkans were split between a Latin speaking and a Greek speaking area of influence. The line dividing both is called ‘Jireček line’, and goes through the middle of Albania, along the Shkumbin river. The two Albanian main dialects, Tosk and Gheg, split at this exact line too - between Eastern Greek and Western Roman influence. At the same time, Christianity before the Great Schism was already kind-of split between a Latin speaking Roman-rite and a Greek-speaking Byzantine rite. The split between these rites may be what caused the Albanian dialect split.Before the Tosk-Gheg split in the 5. Century, Albanians were influenced far stronger by the Latin West than from the Greek East, which expresses itself in 60% Latin loanwords in the modern Albanian language. That means: Albanians originate north of the Jireček line. Many of the latin loans are pre-christian, again showing that the modern, partly romanized Albanian language originates north of the Jireček line in Western Roman influence. And if the first christianization of Albanians preceded the Tosk-Gheg split, the latin-speaking Roman rite of christianity, the predecessor of Catholizism if you like, is the original form of christianity among Albanians - Albanians were taught christianity in latin and not in greek, and the Albanian christianity was originally in the Roman rite - the early form of catholicism.Now we have to keep in mind, that this early Roman ‘version’ of christianity does not equal Catholicism, and scholars are not 100% sure if the christianization of Albanians really preceded the Tosk-Gheg split. If that is not the case, Southern Albanians would be originally ‘Byzantine’-christian and northern Albanians ‘Rome’-christian, as Tosks and Ghegs took the respective forms of christianity of their zone of influence. In the end, whether Catholizism or Orthodoxy, both are a result of two European powers tearing the Albanians into different directions. Early Catholizism is technically the first Albanian monotheistic confession, but today that bears no meaning, aside from being a historical curiosity.
